Latin: is, hic, iste m, ista f

Portuguese: esse m, essa f (near), aquele m, aquela f (far)
Spanish: ése m, ésa f (near), aquél m, aquélla f (far)
uno m, un m (before a masculine noun), una f
Italian: uno m, un m (before a masculine noun), una f
Romanian: unu m, un m (before a masculine noun), una f

Latin: unguis, ungula (nails / claws of an animal)

Portuguese: tripas pl, entranhas pl, intestinos pl
Spanish: tripas pl, intestinos pl, entrañas pl
French: entrailles pl, tripes pl, intestins pl

Italian: tenere (in some dialects means also "to have"), mantenere
spremere, pressare, comprimere, stringere, sprisciare (only for some southern dialects)

Latin: iacere, iactāre, lanceāre (to throw a speer)
fluere, currere (in the sense of "running water")

Romanian: pământ, țară (rare, in the sense of "land")

Italian: rosso, vermiglio (a specific kind of red)
vicino, prossimo less common, propinquo rare, adiacente (for "touching" proximity)

Latin: procul, laxius, distāns, (genitive sg. : distantis), longinquus, longitanus (vulg.)
